James_Bonamy:
{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2020}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = James Bonamy | image = | birth_name = James Michael BonamyFull name per [[Broadcast Music Incorporated]] database | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1972|4|29}} | birth_place = [[Winter Park, Florida]], U.S.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=artist|id=p169900|pure_url=yes}}|title=James Bonamy biography|last=Summers|first=Kim|work=[[Allmusic]]|accessdate=August 31, 2010}} | origin = [[Daytona Beach, Florida]], U.S. | instrument = Vocals, guitar | genre = [[country music|Country]] | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 1995–1997 | label = [[Epic Records|Epic]] | associated_acts = [[Doug Johnson (record producer)|Doug Johnson]] }} '''James Michael Bonamy''' (born April 29, 1972) is an American pastor and former [[country music]] artist. He has released two studio albums (1996's ''[[What I Live to Do]]'' and 1997's ''[[Roots and Wings (James Bonamy album)|Roots and Wings]]''), both on the [[Epic Records]] Nashville label. These albums produced seven singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' Hot Country Singles & Tracks (now [[Hot Country Songs]]) charts, of which the highest-peaking was "[[I Don't Think I Will]]" at number 2. ==Early life== Bonamy was born in [[Winter Park, Florida]] in 1972. Growing up around the beach as well as around dirt car-racing tracks near his home, he played outside linebacker and fullback in high school football. Bonamy's father was of Lebanese descent.{{Cite web|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1996-09-05-9609050091-story.html|title=WITH A NO. 1 HIT, BONAMY IS BARKING UP THE RIGHT TREE|author=Jack Hurst|website=Chicagotribune.com}} He graduated from [[Mainland High School]] in [[Daytona Beach, Florida]] in 1990. After graduating in the fall of 1990, he followed his brother to the University of Alabama. He spent most of his first year sitting in the off-campus apartment he and his brother shared, playing guitar and trying to write country songs. After performing on a local radio show in [[Alabama]], he quit school to work at a gift shop in [[Orlando, Florida]].{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1996-04-26/news/9604240195_1_church-street-station-tammy-wynette-alabama|archive-url=https://archive.today/20120712094326/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1996-04-26/news/9604240195_1_church-street-station-tammy-wynette-alabama|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 12, 2012|title=Florida Native James Bonamy Got Start On Alabama Radio Show|date=April 26, 1996|work=[[Orlando Sentinel]]|accessdate=April 27, 2011}} Later, he performed in a program called "Country Music USA" at the [[Opryland USA]] theme park in [[Nashville, Tennessee]]. Bonamy also competed on ''[[Star Search]]''.{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PBPB&p_theme=pbpb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF3FACD7267493&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=DAYTONA'S BONAMY SERIOUS ABOUT MUSIC|last=Lomartire|first=Paul|date=October 11, 1996|newspaper=[[Palm Beach Post]]|accessdate=October 16, 2011}} ===1995–1996: ''What I Live to Do''=== In 1995, he was signed to [[Epic Records]], and his debut album, ''[[What I Live to Do]]'', was released in 1996 under the production of [[Doug Johnson (record producer)|Doug Johnson]]. The first single, "Dog on a Toolbox," peaked at number 64 on the [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, having been withdrawn as a single because label staff thought that there were too many songs about dogs at the time.{{cite magazine|last=Flippo|first=Chet|date=April 19, 1997|title=James Bonamy Remains Dogged with New Epic Set|magazine=Billboard|pages=30, 55|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9w4EAAAAMBAJ&dq=%22James+bonamy%22&pg=PA30}} After this song was withdrawn, its original [[b-side]], "She's Got a Mind of Her Own" was shipped as the second single.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|year=2008|page=54|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} This song peaked at 26 on the country music charts, followed by the number 2 hit "[[I Don't Think I Will]]" and the number 27 "All I Do Is Love Her." At the 1997 [[Academy of Country Music Awards]], Bonamy was nominated as [[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year|Top New Male Vocalist]], and [[The Nashville Network|TNN]] Music City News nominated him as Star of Tomorrow. In addition, he toured in 1997 with [[Emilio Navaira]], [[Clay Walker]] and [[Terri Clark]]. Dan Kuchar of ''[[Country Standard Time]]'' gave the album a mixed review, praising Bonamy's voice but criticizing the songwriting on most of the tracks and saying that the album did not have a distinctive sound.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1291|title=''What I Live to Do'' review|last=Kuchar|first=Dan|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=August 31, 2010}} ===1997: ''Roots and Wings''=== A second album, ''[[Roots and Wings (James Bonamy album)|Roots and Wings]]'', followed in 1997.{{Cite web|url=https://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/James-Bonamy.html|title=James Bonamy Biography|website=Oldies.com|accessdate=December 1, 2019}} Its lead-off single "[[The Swing (song)|The Swing]]" was his last top 40 hit at number 31; the other two singles were "Naked to the Pain" and "Little Blue Dot", reaching numbers 65 and 63 respectively. Bonamy wrote the track "I Knew I'd Need My Heart Someday" with Johnson and [[Pat Bunch]], and chose the title track (which was written by [[Skip Ewing]] and [[Bill Anderson (singer)|Bill Anderson]] and previously recorded by [[Doug Supernaw]]) at the suggestion of Epic's A&R director, Debbie Zavitson. This album also received a mixed review from ''Country Standard Time'', with Larry Stevens praising "Daddy Never Had a Chance in Hell" but criticizing the rest of the album for having a more pop-oriented sound.{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/d/cdreview.asp?xid=1290|title=''Roots and Wings'' review|last=Stephens|first=Larry|work=Country Standard Time|accessdate=August 31, 2010}} Thom Owens of [[Allmusic]] gave a three-star rating out of five, saying that he considered it an improvement over the debut.{{cite web|url={{AllMusic|class=album|id=r277854|pure_url=yes}}|title=''Roots and Wings'' review|last=Owens|first=Thom|work=Allmusic|accessdate=August 31, 2010}} ==Personal life== Bonamy has not recorded an album since 1997. By 2002, he had moved to [[Cypress, Texas]], where he worked at a communications company.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1458841/hot-talk-another-tour-more-books-thanksgiving-and-lost-stars/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729050256/http://www.cmt.com/news/1458841/hot-talk-another-tour-more-books-thanksgiving-and-lost-stars/|url-status=dead|archive-date=July 29, 2017|title=HOT TALK: Another Tour, More Books, Thanksgiving and Lost Stars|first=Edward|last=Morris|website=Cmt.com|accessdate=December 1, 2019}} He served full time as a Worship Pastor at [[Christ Fellowship]] in [[Palm Beach Gardens, Florida]] from 2010 to 2012.{{cite web|url=http://gochristfellowship.com/events/night-of-prayer-encounter/|title=Night of Prayer Encounter|work=Christ Fellowship|accessdate=July 11, 2011}}{{Dead link|date=January 2020 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He is married to Amy Jane and has three sons, Daniel, Paul and Sal, and currently lives in Longview, Texas where he is a Pastor at his church home, Grace Creek Church. ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:12em;"| Title ! rowspan="2" style="width:18em;"| Album details ! colspan="3"| Peak chart positions |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Top Country Albums|US Country]] ! width="45"| [[Billboard 200|US]] ! width="45"| [[Top Heatseekers|US Heat]] |- ! scope="row"| ''[[What I Live to Do]]'' | * Release date: February 20, 1996 * Label: [[Epic Records]] | 16 | 112 | 1 |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Roots and Wings (James Bonamy album)|Roots and Wings]]'' | * Release date: June 24, 1997 * Label: Epic Records | 25 | — | 11 |- | colspan="5" style="font-size:8pt"| "—" denotes releases that did not chart |- |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart
